vulnerabilities.description: Reflected XSS vulnerability detected in parameter 'searchFor'. The application does not properly sanitize user input before including it in the HTML response. Attackers can inject malicious JavaScript code to steal session cookies, perform actions on behalf of users, or deface the website.
vulnerabilities.evidence:
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
"http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html><!-- InstanceBegin template="/Templates/main_dynamic_template.dwt.php" codeOutsideHTMLIsLocked="false" -->
<head>
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-2">

<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="document_title_rgn" -->
<title>Home of Acunetix Art</title>
<!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
<link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css" type="text/css">
<!-- InstanceBeginEditab
vulnerabilities.remediation:
1. Implement proper output encoding/escaping for all user-controlled data.
2. Use Content Security Policy (CSP) headers to restrict script execution.
3. Validate and sanitize all user input on the server side.
4. Use HTTPOnly flags on cookies to prevent JavaScript access.
5. Consider using security libraries or frameworks with built-in XSS protection.
6. Implement input validation with allowlists rather than denylists.

vulnerabilities.description: CSRF vulnerability detected: Missing CSRF token. The form (action: search.php?test=query, method: post) does not have adequate CSRF protection. While this form may not perform highly sensitive actions, CSRF protection should still be implemented to prevent unauthorized requests.
vulnerabilities.remediation:
1. Implement CSRF tokens (also called anti-CSRF tokens or synchronizer tokens).
2. Use the Synchronizer Token Pattern: generate a unique token for each session/request.
3. Validate the token on the server side for all state-changing operations.
4. Set the SameSite cookie attribute to 'Strict' or 'Lax' for session cookies.
5. For sensitive operations, require re-authentication or additional verification.
6. Implement proper CORS policies to restrict cross-origin requests.
7. Use security frameworks that provide built-in CSRF protection (e.g., Django, Spring Security).
